articles.headline: News Corp. Loss Shows Trouble at Dow Jones
articles.snippet: The media company, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a quarterly loss of $6.41 billion on a write-down of Dow Jones & Co. and other assets, as the recession hit advertising revenue.
articles.abstract: The media company, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, reported a quarterly loss of $6.41 billion on a write-down of Dow Jones & Co. and other assets, as the recession hit advertising revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems that even Rupert Murdoch isn’t immune to the downturn battering media companies.

articles.headline: The Upside to Resisting Globalization
articles.snippet: While countries with closed economies may have missed out on some opportunities for growth in recent decades, they are now better positioned to weather the global downturn.
articles.abstract: While countries with closed economies may have missed out on some opportunities for growth in recent decades, they are now better positioned to weather the global downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: As globalization spread in recent decades, the pace of world economic growth picked up. Open economies, it turns out, can grow faster than closed ones.

articles.headline: Japan’s Big-Works Stimulus Is Lesson
articles.snippet: Over two decades, Japan accumulated enormous debt while failing to generate a convincing recovery.
articles.abstract: Over two decades, Japan accumulated enormous debt while failing to generate a convincing recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMADA, Japan — The Hamada Marine Bridge soars majestically over this small fishing harbor, so much larger than the squid boats anchored below that it seems out of place.

articles.headline: Trying to Help Financially Troubled Homeowners
articles.snippet: A plan backed by the Obama administration would help desperate homeowners stay in their houses while they renegotiate their debt.
articles.abstract: A plan backed by the Obama administration would help desperate homeowners stay in their houses while they renegotiate their debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: People seem to pass certain milestones on the road of financial desperation. First the unpaid bills pile up. Then the bank forecloses. Finally, they reach the end of the line: bankruptcy court.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Possible Link Between Dam and China Quake
articles.snippet: The weight of a reservoir a mile from a major fault may have triggered the 2008 earthquake in Sichuan Province.
articles.abstract: The weight of a reservoir a mile from a major fault may have triggered the 2008 earthquake in Sichuan Province.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  Nearly nine months after a devastating earthquake in Sichuan Province, China, left 80,000 people dead or missing, a growing number of American and Chinese scientists are suggesting that the calamity was triggered by a four-year-old reservoir built close to the earthquake’s geological fault line.

articles.headline: More Names of Note Appear on Madoff List
articles.snippet: Boldfaced names mingle with the unheard of on a list of 13,567 people drawn into the Bernard Madoff case.
articles.abstract: Boldfaced names mingle with the unheard of on a list of 13,567 people drawn into the Bernard Madoff case.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time  was it only two months ago?  when people would have been proud to be on a list of Bernard L. Madoff’s customers. They had made the cut, and their money was getting the Madoff touch, growing steadily and solidly in good times and bad.

articles.headline: As Layoffs Surge, Women May Pass Men in Job Force
articles.snippet: With the downturn hurting industries that employ more men, women may surpass them on the nation’s payrolls.
articles.abstract: With the downturn hurting industries that employ more men, women may surpass them on the nation’s payrolls.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the recession on the brink of becoming the longest in the postwar era, a milestone may be at hand: Women are poised to surpass men on the nation’s payrolls, taking the majority for the first time in American history.

articles.headline: British Bank Adapts to Life on a Leash
articles.snippet: After a bailout that has made the British government its most influential shareholder, the Royal Bank of Scotland’s once cosseted executives are adjusting to a life that is both leaner and meaner.
articles.abstract: After a bailout that has made the British government its most influential shareholder, the Royal Bank of Scotland’s once cosseted executives are adjusting to a life that is both leaner and meaner.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Wall Street’s finest may be grumbling over the new bonus restrictions imposed by the Obama administration, but it could be worse: they could be working for the Royal Bank of Scotland.

articles.headline: Economy Shed 598,000 Jobs in January
articles.snippet: The losses reinforced the picture of an economy contracting at its fastest pace in decades.
articles.abstract: The losses reinforced the picture of an economy contracting at its fastest pace in decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Though job losses accelerated last month, the United States has not yet hit bottom.

articles.headline: Pakistan Frees Nuclear Dealer in Snub to U.S.
articles.snippet: Abdul Qadeer Khan, history’s most successful nuclear proliferator, was freed from house arrest on Friday.
articles.abstract: Abdul Qadeer Khan, history’s most successful nuclear proliferator, was freed from house arrest on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A Pakistani court freed one of the most successful nuclear proliferators in history, Abdul Qadeer Khan, from house arrest on Friday, lifting the restrictions imposed on him since 2004 when he publicly confessed to running an illicit nuclear network.
articles.byline: By Salman Masood and David E. Sanger
